columns.text: In this problem, we are given two options and we need to determine which of these two will be able to generate the highest aftertax income.

For this problem, there are two options. The first option is to reinvest the dividends and get it after three years. The second option is to get the dividends now. 

There are also subparts for each option. The money can be reinvested in either Treasury bills or preferred stock. Basically, the options provided are:

**A.** Company reinvests in treasury bills\
**B.** Company reinvests in preferred stock\
**C.** Client invests in treasury bills\
**D.** Client invests in preferred stock

In order to determine which is the better option, we need to solve for the aftertax cashflow of the four options.

Before we solve for the aftertax cashflow of the different options, we must first list down the given values. 

For options A and C:
| Pre tax rate of return for Treasury bills|2.5% | 
|--|--| 
|Amount to be invested |$4,000,000 | 
|Number of years |3 years | 
| Corporate tax rate| 21%| 
|Personal common stock dividend tax rate |15% |

For Option B and D:

| Pre tax rate of return for preferred stock| 4.3%| 
|--|--| 
| Amount to be invested|$4,000,000 | 
| Number of years|3 | 
| Corporate tax rate|21% | 
|Tax exemption |70% | 
| Personal common stock dividend tax rate  |15% |

Now that we have the given values, we can now solve for the aftertax profits of each option. 

Starting with Option A, we can first solve for the aftertax rate of return using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After tax rate of return for treasury bills}&=\text{Pre tax rate of return}\\
&\times(1-\text{Corporate tax rate})\\[15 pt]
&=0.025 \times (1-0.21)\\
&=0.01975
\end{aligned}$$

From this, we can then solve for the future value of the investment using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Future value of investment}&=\text{Present value} \times (1+\text{Aftertax rate})^\text{Number of years}\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,000,000 \times(1+0.01975)^3\\
&=\$4,241,711.565
\end{aligned}$$

The future value of the investment is $\$4,241,711.565$.

Now, to get the aftertax profit, we can take the value above and multiply it to one minus the personal common stock dividend rate:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After tax profit for Option A}&=\$4,241,711.565 \times (1-0.15)\\
&=\$3,605,454.83
\end{aligned}$$

The after tax profit for Option A is $\$3,605,454.843$.

For Option B, we must first solve for the after tax rate of the preferred stock using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After tax rate for preferred stock}&=\text{Pretax rate}-(\text{Pretax rate}\times(1-\text{Tax exemption})\times \text{Corporate tax rate})\\[15 pt]
&=0.043-(0.043\times(1-0.7)\times0.21\\
&=0.040291
\end{aligned}$$

We can then get the future value of the investment using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Future value of investment}&=\text{Present value} \times (1+\text{Aftertax rate})^\text{Number of years}\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,000,000 \times(1+0.040291)^3\\
&=\$4,503,234.004
\end{aligned}$$

The future value of the investment is $\$4,503,234.004$.

Now, to get the aftertax profit, we can take the value above and multiply it to one minus the personal common stock dividend rate:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After tax profit for Option B}&=\$4,503,234.004 \times (1-0.15)\\
&=\$3,827,748.903
\end{aligned}$$

The after tax profit for Option B is $\$3,827,748.903$.

For Option C, we can first solve for the aftertax rate of return using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After tax rate of return for treasury bills}&=\text{Pre tax rate of return}\\
&\times(1-\text{Personal common stock dividend tax rate})\\[15 pt]
&=0.025 \times (1-0.15)\\
&=0.02125
\end{aligned}$$

Moreover, we will solve for the total amount that can be invested based on the personal common stock dividend tax rate. To do this, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Amount to be invested}&=\text{Present value} \times (1-\text{Personal common stock dividend tax rate})\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,000,000 \times (1-0.15)\\
&=\$3,400,000
\end{aligned}$$

The amount to be invested is now $\$3,400,000$.

Finally, to get the aftertax value of this option, we can simply solve for its future value using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Future value of investment}&=\text{Amount to be invested} \times (1+\text{Aftertax rate})^\text{Number of years}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,400,000 \times(1+0.02125)^3\\
&=\$3,621,388.563
\end{aligned}$$

The aftertax value of this investment is $\$3,621,388.563$.

Finally, for Option D we will first solve for the after tax rate for preferred stocks

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After tax rate of return for preferred stock}&=\text{Pre tax rate of return}\\
&\times(1-\text{Personal common stock dividend tax rate})\\[15 pt]
&=0.043 \times (1-0.15)\\
&=0.03655
\end{aligned}$$

Moreover, we will solve for the total amount that can be invested based on the personal common stock dividend tax rate. To do this, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Amount to be invested}&=\text{Present value} \times (1-\text{Personal common stock dividend tax rate})\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,000,000 \times (1-0.15)\\
&=\$3,400,000
\end{aligned}$$

The amount to be invested is now $\$3,400,000$.

To get the aftertax value of this option, we can simply solve for its future value using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Future value of investment}&=\text{Amount to be invested} \times (1+\text{Aftertax rate})^\text{Number of years}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,400,000 \times(1+0.03655)^3\\
&=\$3,786,602.218
\end{aligned}$$

The aftertax value of this investment is $\$3,786,602.218$.

As we can see from the values that we solved, the option that provides the highest aftertax profits is **Option B** which is the company will hold and invest the money in preferred stock and give the profits after 3 years. 

This means that the cash should be paid after three years and it should first be invested in preferred stock.
